STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 17, 2025
Linda Needham
Lenawee County DHHS
1040 S Winter St.,
Adrian, MI, 49221-3876
RE: License#: CP460201242
Dear Ms. Needham:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 9/16/25. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368,
MCL 333.5111. All the following apply: (ii) A copy of a
waiver addressed to the department that is signed by
the parent stating immunizations are not being
administered due to religious, medical, or other
reasons is sufficient documentation of immunizations,
unless the child is a temporary court ward, a motion is
heard, and order is entered by the circuit court for the
child's case. A waiver must be accompanied by a
certification by the local health department that the
parent or parents received education on the risks of not
receiving the vaccines being waived and the benefits of
vaccination to the individual and the community as
required by section 5111 of the public health code,
1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111, and R 325.176(12).
Three of six foster care files had one missing immunization each.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/23 Renewal, CAP approved 10/12/23.

CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation from
the medical or dental provider of all medical and dental
care received by a foster child.
One of six foster care files did not have documentation of an annual well-child
exam.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
(PATP) with the parent or parents and foster parents.
The agency must inform the parent or parents and
foster parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Three of six foster care cases held PATPs that were not signed to indicate a copy
was provide to or reviewed with the parent or foster parent/relative caregiver.
CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record
(3) The record must contain all the following
information: (g) A photograph taken at least annually.
Two of six foster care files did not have a current photo of the youth uploaded to
MiSACWIS.
CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record
(2) An agency shall protect each record against
destruction and damage and store and maintain each
child's record in a manner to ensure confidentiality and
to prevent unauthorized access.
During a walkthrough of the agency it was observed that foster care files were not
stored securely. Case files were stored on open shelves at the case manager’s
desks.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Immunizations: The agency was advised that if a foster parent does not take
appropriate actions for youth to receive immunizations, a special evaluation
should be initiated. If a relative caregiver does not take appropriate actions,
efforts must be documented, and the case worker should schedule an
appointment for immunizations. If the youth’s physician determines there are
more urgent medical needs and the immunizations should be postponed, the
agency must have documentation in the file to indicate a plan for immunizations.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment In Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period in response to the 2024 Inspection, and compliance with each
individual CAP is as follows: The agency reported implementing the CAP through
utilization of a new hire/intern checklist and increased oversight through the book
of business for due dates related to foster care and Independent Living. The CAP
appears to have been effective as there were no repeat violations from 2024
during this review. There was one repeat violation regarding immunizations from
2023 which will be addressed in a new CAP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) Annual Assessment dated 9/11/25 was reviewed
and discussed. The Chief Administrator reported the 2024 CAP had been
implemented to address areas of non-compliance with personnel files, service
plans, and placement change. The CA did not identify any systemic barriers.
However, they did report that inconsistent use of the book of business may have
been the cause of the violations. The agency implemented strategies to prevent
further repeat violations. The CA reported key performance indicators from
August 2025 show high compliance in most areas. The CA reported ten placement
disruptions during this review period. The main reason for disrupted placements
was youth needing a higher level of care than what was available in their

placement and hospital stabilization was needed. The CA reported that nine of the
placement disruptions were youth placed in residential, who needed
hospitalization for stabilization, then returned to the residential treatment program.
The tenth youth was in a court ordered placement, in which the provider struggled
to meet their needs for safe boundaries and structure. Once the youth moved to a
placement with a higher level of care, stability occurred.
Financial Overview
Not applicable.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. Both staff reported they enjoy their position
and feel the workload is manageable. Both staff stated their supervisors are
supportive, understand the work, and they are easy to talk with. Staff reported that
the whole office works well together, supports one another, and communicates
well. Staff stated they were happy with the organization as a whole and did not
have any concerns, or suggestions for improvement.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same building as the 2024 review. The
building had sufficient space for staff and clients to meet and hold visitation. The
agency did not have locking file storage, as reflected in the violation of rule
400.12422 (2). The agency reported they have ordered shelves to be placed in a
locking room, as a solution for this violation.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two identified safety alerts:
Safety Alert #1: On 7/17/25 the Agency Analyst observed a home did not have a
carbon monoxide detector. The home also did not have a smoke detector in the
basement.
Resolution #1: The caregiver and agency worked together to obtain a smoke alarm
and carbon monoxide detector. These were installed on 7/21/25. Photos were
provided to DCWL as verification.
Safety Alert #2: On 8/27/25 a safety alert was issued as the caregivers did not
respond to multiple requests from the Agency Analyst to schedule a visit.
Resolution #2: The agency initiated a special evaluation. A home visit was
conducted by the agency on 8/27/25. No safety concerns were noted. The family
reportedly failed to schedule with the analyst due to their busy schedule and not
prioritizing the visit.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.

_ __________September 16, 2025________________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
